quiz.name: Module 1: The Firm and Market Structures
quiz.subtopic: Module 1: The Firm and Market Structures

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08061
entry.itemBody: Firms operating under a monopolistic competition market structure most likely:

choices.itemBody: C. sell products that are close substitutes for those offered by other firms.

answerFeedback.0ba3dd15-a2ed-45a9-af99-e2aa5e05d249: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition, there are a large number of potential buyers and sellers.
answerFeedback.2de04929-61ba-4ad0-8cb2-eb1d206e6d0d: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition, entry into and exit from the market are possible with fairly low costs. Furthermore, barriers to entry in a monopolistic competition market structure are low.
answerFeedback.9293afe4-0ebc-4c1f-abca-315e5bd66e56: Correct because under monopolistic competition, the products offered by each seller are close substitutes for the products offered by other firms, and each firm tries to make its product look different.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531083
entry.itemBody: A market structure characterized by homogeneous/standardized product differentiation is best described as:

answerFeedback.0c7492c7-0ed8-4102-b38a-03ca12b7b209: Incorrect because monopolistic competition does not have a standardized product.
answerFeedback.97be9667-4490-4c37-bea4-0ccd94ac7edf: Incorrect because a monopoly does not have a standardized product.
answerFeedback.c5799a3a-67f0-4515-8723-b1efd4611a93:
Correct. Perfect competition and oligopoly are characterized by homogeneous/standardized product differentiation.

Market Structure Degree of Product Differentiation
Perfect competition Homogeneous/standardized
Monopolistic competition Differentiated
Oligopoly Homogeneous/standardized
Monopoly Unique product

entry.title: ITEM_20190530019
entry.itemBody: Which of the following statements about a downward-sloping long-run average cost (LRAC) curve is most accurate? A downward-sloping LRAC curve is representative of a firm experiencing:

answerFeedback.2e74fd0c-5db1-4566-bc79-82b7b301085c: Correct. When the LRAC curve is downward sloping, it means the firm is producing units at lower average costs per unit as production levels rise. This situation represents economies of scale in production.
answerFeedback.3eeea363-82de-48dc-8e3e-b0389fc551ab: Incorrect. An upward-sloping LRAC curve would be representative of diseconomies of scale.
answerFeedback.9f76c6a1-0e2d-4375-ab9b-bf36fc57ff2b: Incorrect. Decreasing levels of investment alone would not result in a downward-sloping LRAC curve; it would also depend on the volume of production. If the level of production drops proportionately more than the level of investment, the LRAC curve could be upward sloping.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10169
entry.itemBody: In a perfectly competitive market, a firm's breakeven point is the minimum point of the:

answerFeedback.249b1867-dedb-4481-96e9-eaab903bd77c: Correct because economists refer to the minimum AVC point as the shutdown point and the minimum ATC point as the breakeven point.
answerFeedback.50be5183-9538-4e3b-b10a-ebf43c079261: Incorrect because economists refer to the minimum AVC point as the shutdown point and the minimum ATC point as the breakeven point.
answerFeedback.a7045c95-045a-4cc4-9f78-ae2adb9e22c3: Incorrect because economists refer to the minimum AVC point as the shutdown point and the minimum ATC point as the breakeven point. The AFC curve does not have a minimum point because it decreases throughout the production span, reflecting the spreading of a constant cost over more and more production units.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Islam-03
entry.itemBody: In the long run, a monopolistically competitive firm:

choices.itemBody: C. produces at a higher level of average cost than the minimum average cost.

answerFeedback.09a57b25-db0f-48f2-b124-ec3f6da528e1: Correct because in the hybrid market of monopolistic competition, zero economic profit in long-run equilibrium resembles perfect competition. However, the long-run level of output, Q1, is less than Q2, which corresponds to the minimum average cost of production and would be the long-run level of output in a perfectly competitive market.
answerFeedback.506555bf-0bbb-41c9-85ae-0e25cfb492c2: Incorrect because in the hybrid market of monopolistic competition, zero economic profit in long-run equilibrium resembles perfect competition.
answerFeedback.df28d5cb-8045-4a8e-8958-44c02de89937: Incorrect because each good sold in the product group is somewhat different from the others, the demand curve for each firm in the monopolistic competition market structure is downward sloping to the right. Price and the quantity demanded are negatively related. If the environment of the firm is perfectly competitive, it must take the market price of its output as given, so it faces a perfectly elastic, horizontal demand curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Econ-Grabe-06
entry.itemBody: In an oligopoly market, which of the following best describes the situation when firms have no incentive to deviate from their current pricing strategy based on the anticipated choices of competitors?

answerFeedback.6eda77bc-5079-4fa2-ae19-f8f14e7e2b62: Incorrect because if there is pricing interdependence competitors will match a price reduction and ignore a price increase, indicating competitors believe they have an incentive to adjust their strategy based on observed competitor choices.
answerFeedback.8412d92e-9c2d-4ecf-946b-79e7bd2f801d: Correct because the Nash equilibrium is present when two or more participants in a non- cooperative game have no incentive to deviate from their respective equilibrium strategies after they have considered and anticipated their opponent’s rational choices or strategies.
answerFeedback.d35491bb-0ec6-4419-97d2-440e43e60569: Incorrect because in the Stackelberg model the leader firm chooses its output first and then the follower firm chooses after observing the leader's output, indicating followers see an incentive to adjust their strategies based on the observed choices of leaders.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Shaw-05
entry.itemBody: In which of the following market structures does marginal revenue equal price?

answerFeedback.5a842143-3247-42bf-b6be-93c8ad4ee2ca: Correct because only in perfect competition does the marginal revenue equal price. In the remaining structures, price generally exceeds marginal revenue because a firm can sell more units only by reducing the per unit price.
answerFeedback.7118dc6e-6237-41e9-bd52-8dbae58a7fbf: Incorrect because only in perfect competition does the marginal revenue equal price. In the remaining structures, price generally exceeds marginal revenue because a firm can sell more units only by reducing the per unit price.
answerFeedback.f3428698-85d4-4527-92c2-ce0b39c65c23: Incorrect because only in perfect competition does the marginal revenue equal price. In the remaining structures, price generally exceeds marginal revenue because a firm can sell more units only by reducing the per unit price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10171
entry.itemBody: The perfectly competitive firm's supply curve is its long-run:

answerFeedback.34a2526d-f010-4596-8f34-8ddde6e68568: Incorrect because the long-run marginal cost schedule (not the average total cost schedule) is the perfectly competitive firm's supply curve.
answerFeedback.46b176ca-bb75-48e2-9cfb-d1947fda27a0: Incorrect because the firm's demand schedule is the same as the firm's marginal revenue and average revenue.
answerFeedback.f1f586cd-ffda-4ecf-ad3f-53d0451a6c83: Correct because the long-run marginal cost schedule is the perfectly competitive firm's supply curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10225
entry.itemBody: To calculate the Herfindahl–Hirschman index:

choices.itemBody: A. add the market shares of the largest firms.
B. add the market shares of the largest firms and then square the sum.
C. square the market shares of the largest firms and then add the results.

answerFeedback.5ca06ec7-8777-49b8-a797-5df811a7f879: Correct because to avoid the known issues with concentration ratios, economists O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added.
answerFeedback.dca5632e-8e9a-4283-8244-85560c10680d: Incorrect because to avoid the known issues with concentration ratios, economists O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added.
answerFeedback.fb30b733-54ac-4483-b31c-03cf5620003d: Incorrect because adding the firms' market shares would calculate the concentration ratio, not the HHI.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Horvath-01
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information about three markets:

  Number of Sellers Non-Price Competition
Market 1 Many None
Market 2 Few Strong
Market 3  Many Strong

Which market is most likely an oligopoly?

answerFeedback.79469c12-ee18-4ff8-b650-9c1983688f8a: Incorrect because in an oligopoly market there are a small (not large) number of potential sellers and products are often highly differentiated through marketing, features, and other non-price strategies. Market 1 resembles the characteristics of perfect competition.
answerFeedback.a016e6a9-df6d-424f-8fbc-d5b03ae6b8ec: Correct because in an oligopoly market there are a small number of potential sellers and products are often highly differentiated through marketing, features, and other non-price strategies.
answerFeedback.d780776f-499d-4ab8-a33b-da646ec060bc: Incorrect because in an oligopoly market there are a small (not large) number of potential sellers and products are often highly differentiated through marketing, features, and other non-price strategies. Market 3 resembles the characteristics of monopolistic competition.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020A-Econ-Grabe-07
entry.itemBody: Monopolistic competition is best characterized by:

choices.itemBody: B. a small number of buyers and sellers.

answerFeedback.516e6177-356b-4648-a48f-a57695b5db55: Incorrect because for a monopolistically competitive firm: there are a large number of potential buyers and sellers.
answerFeedback.59959d24-f671-45ea-b3f9-2ae916199703: Correct because for a monopolistically competitive firm: suppliers differentiate their products through advertising and other non-price strategies.
answerFeedback.d957ecb3-2916-4dbf-9d36-47eddeea730b: Incorrect because for a monopolistically competitive firm: entry into and exit from the market are possible with fairly low costs.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-01114
entry.itemBody: If a perfectly competitive industry becomes monopolistically competitive, each firm's long-run average total cost per unit sold will most likely:

answerFeedback.187ae05b-c3af-4468-bfea-b7c36c088f5e: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition each firm does not produce the efficient quantity, whereas under perfect competition each firm does produce the efficient quantity. Therefore, average total cost is minimized under perfect competition.
answerFeedback.d24618b7-7b88-4bc6-9c0b-24394420daad: Correct because unlike long-run equilibrium in perfect competition, in the market of monopolistic competition, the equilibrium position is at a higher level of average cost than the level of output that minimizes average cost. Average cost does not reach its minimum until output level Q2 is achieved. Under perfect competition a product is produced at the efficient quantity (marginal revenue equals marginal cost) and average total cost is minimized. The demand faced by each firm is perfectly elastic (horizontal demand curve). However, under monopolistic competition the demand curve is downward sloping and the quantity produced (marginal revenue equals marginal cost) is not where average total cost is minimized. Thus, average total cost is lower under perfect competition.
answerFeedback.ef961e72-1b84-4db3-868b-b34c8b6c9208: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition each firm does not produce the efficient quantity, whereas under perfect competition each firm does produce the efficient quantity. Therefore, average total cost is minimized under perfect competition.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-05391
entry.itemBody: If a monopolistically competitive industry becomes perfectly competitive, each firm's long-run average total cost per unit sold will most likely:

answerFeedback.9c9bbfb9-553f-4c17-a9d9-c9849e66160e: Correct because under perfect competition a product is produced at the efficient quantity (marginal revenue equals marginal cost) and the average total cost is minimized. The demand curve faced by each firm is perfectly elastic (horizontal demand curve). However, under monopolistic competition the demand curve is downward sloping and the quantity produced (marginal revenue equals marginal cost) is not where average total cost is minimized. Thus, average total cost is lower under perfect competition.
answerFeedback.b6e15a9a-ea2d-4ff5-98bb-5e6f929d5eb4: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition each firm does not produce the efficient quantity, whereas in perfect competition, each firm does produce the efficient quantity. Since production occurs at the efficient level in perfect competition, average total cost is minimized.
answerFeedback.e0b26107-825b-4308-ad1b-a208403d964b: Incorrect because under monopolistic competition each firm does not produce the efficient quantity, whereas in perfect competition, each firm does produce the efficient quantity. Since production occurs at the efficient level in perfect competition, average total cost is minimized.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08744
entry.itemBody: In the short run, the shutdown point of a company with a total variable cost of $3 million and a total fixed cost of $5 million is when total revenue declines to:

answerFeedback.23fb1645-2614-4ef5-bcf1-0d58d1703d61: Incorrect because in the short run the company will shut down production when total revenue is less than total variable costs of $3 million, not less than total cost of $8 million.
answerFeedback.5d8b23be-2c35-4b0f-bf9e-ad239bbc1549: Incorrect because in the short run the company will shut down production when total revenue is less than total variable cost of $3 million, not total fixed cost of $5 million.
answerFeedback.ed20fe3e-d148-46ed-ab6f-003287e4b2a5: Correct because as long as the firm’s revenues cover at least its variable cost, the firm is better off continuing to operate. If price is greater than average variable cost (AVC), the firm is covering not only all of its variable cost but also a portion of fixed cost. Also, average revenue (AR) is revenue per unit.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q12
entry.itemBody: The short-term shutdown point of production for a firm operating under perfect competition will most likely occur when:

choices.itemBody: A. price is equal to average total cost.
B. marginal revenue is equal to marginal cost.
C. marginal revenue is equal to average variable costs.

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The firm should shut down production when marginal revenue is less than or equal to average variable cost.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q13
entry.itemBody: Under conditions of perfect competition, a company will break even when market price is equal to the minimum point of the:

feedback.neutral: A is correct. A company is said to break even if its total revenue is equal to its total cost. Under conditions of perfect competition, a company will break even when market price is equal to the minimum point of the average total cost curve.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q14
entry.itemBody: A company will shut down production in the short run if total revenue is less than total:

feedback.neutral: B is correct. A company will shut down production in the short run when total revenue is below total variable costs.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q15
entry.itemBody: A company has total variable costs of $4 million and fixed costs of $3 million. Based on this information, the company will stay in the market in the long term if total revenue is at least:

feedback.neutral: C is correct. A company will stay in the market in the long term if total revenue is equal to or greater than total cost. Because total costs are $7 million ($4 million variable costs and $3 million fixed costs), the company will stay in the market in the long term if total revenue equals at least $7 million.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q16
entry.itemBody: When total revenue is greater than total variable costs but less than total costs, in the short term, a firm will most likely:

feedback.neutral: B is correct. When total revenue is enough to cover variable costs but not total fixed costs in full, the firm can survive in the short run but would not be able to maintain financial solvency in the long run.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q17
entry.itemBody: Under conditions of perfect competition, in the long run, firms will most likely earn:

feedback.neutral: A is correct. Competition should drive prices down to long-run marginal cost, resulting in only normal profits being earned.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q18
entry.itemBody: A firm that increases its quantity produced without any change in per-unit cost is experiencing:

feedback.neutral: C is correct. Output increases in the same proportion as input increases occur at constant returns to scale.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q19
entry.itemBody: A company is experiencing economies of scale when:

choices.itemBody: A. cost per unit increases as output increases.
B. it is operating at a point on the LRAC curve at which the slope is negative.
C. it is operating beyond the minimum point on the long-run average total cost curve.

feedback.neutral: B is correct. Economies of scale occur if, as the firm increases output, cost per unit of production falls. Graphically, this definition translates into an LRAC with a negative slope.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q20
entry.itemBody: Diseconomies of scale most likely result from:

choices.itemBody: A. specialization in the labor force.
B. overlap of business functions and product lines.
C. discounted prices on resources when buying in larger quantities.

feedback.neutral: B is correct. As the firm increases output, diseconomies of scale and higher average total costs can result when business functions and product lines overlap or are duplicated.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s02-Q21
entry.itemBody: A firm is operating beyond minimum efficient scale in a perfectly competitive industry. To maintain long-term viability, the most likely course of action for the firm is to:

choices.itemBody: A. operate at the current level of production.
B. increase its level of production to gain economies of scale.
C. decrease its level of production to the minimum point on the long-run average total cost curve.

feedback.neutral: C is correct. The firm operating at greater than long-run efficient scale is subject to diseconomies of scale. It should plan to decrease its level of production.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s05-Q7
entry.itemBody: Companies most likely have a well-defined supply function when the market structure is:

feedback.neutral: B is correct. A company in a perfectly competitive market must accept whatever price the market dictates. The marginal cost schedule of a company in a perfectly competitive market determines its supply function.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s05-Q8
entry.itemBody: Aquarius, Inc. is the dominant company and the price leader in its market. One of the other companies in the market attempts to gain market share by undercutting the price set by Aquarius. The market share of Aquarius will most likely:

feedback.neutral: A is correct. As prices decrease, smaller companies will leave the market rather than sell below cost. The market share of Aquarius, the price leader, will increase.

entry.title: CFA2410-R-s05-Q9
entry.itemBody: Over time, the market share of the dominant company in an oligopolistic market will most likely:

feedback.neutral: B is correct. The dominant company’s market share tends to decrease as profits attract entry by other companies.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531021
entry.itemBody:
Three firms operate under perfect competition, producing 900 units of the same product but using different production technologies. Each company’s cost structure is indicated in the table:
Company X Y Z
Total Variable Costs $2,700 $3,600 $4,500
Total Fixed Costs 2,700 1,800 900
Total Costs $5,400 $5,400 $5,400

Which of the following statements is most accurate? If the unit selling price is:

choices.itemBody: A. $6.00, all firms should exit the market in the long run.
B. $3.00, Firm X should continue to operate in the short run, but Firms Y and Z should shut down production.
C. $4.50, all firms should continue to operate in the short run, but exit the market in the long run if these conditions are expected to persist.

answerFeedback.339d007f-d386-499c-836f-5fdb862052b8:
Correct.

Revenue–Cost Relationship Short-Run Decision Long-Term Decision
TR ≥ TC Stay in market Stay in market
TR > TVC but TR < TFC + TVC Stay in market Exit market
TR < TVC Shut down production Exit market

TR = Total Revenue; TC = Total Costs; TVC = Total Variable Costs; TFC = Total Fixed Costs

Hence, if the selling price is $3.00, total revenue for all firms will be $3.00/unit × 900 units = $2,700. Only Firm X’s variable costs are covered and it should continue operating, while Firms Y and Z should immediately shut down production.
answerFeedback.43590381-a0b3-44fa-8ddf-2dc40920025d: Incorrect. If total revenue equals or exceeds total costs, the firms should remain in the market both in the long and short run: each firm is just earning an economic profit, which includes its opportunity cost.
answerFeedback.da61c63c-67cb-43e3-b391-a189374fe957: Incorrect. At $4.50, total revenue is $4.50 × 900 = $4,050. Only Firms X and Y cover their variable costs; Firm Z should shut down. It is true, however, that if conditions persist, all should shut down in the long run as they won’t be covering their total costs.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531037
entry.itemBody: Which characteristic is a firm least likely to exhibit if it faces a downward sloping demand curve for its product(s), many competitors, and zero economic profits in the long run?

answerFeedback.25477af8-deed-43f8-a81c-3fd89d5e2bde: Incorrect. Product differentiation is a characteristic of monopolistic competition.
answerFeedback.98791b7d-2974-4eee-b7b3-90dd503800aa: Incorrect. Low barriers to entry are a characteristic of monopolistic competition.
answerFeedback.d0f5a4fc-1551-474e-8f7f-e2dd9fa9ec67: Correct. The characteristics of monopolistic competition include a large number of competitors, low pricing power, and the production of differentiated products (through advertising and other non-price strategies), but these still result in some pricing power. The ease of entry results in zero economic profits in the long run.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531046
entry.itemBody: Successful advertising and product differentiation are most likely to have a positive impact on the economic profits of a producer under:

answerFeedback.6a9455e3-6ed2-4656-9904-780ccefb8b32: Incorrect. Under monopoly, advertising and product differentiation are of little consequence in determining economic profits.
answerFeedback.7f925863-2200-4d5d-ab19-a0788774385c: Incorrect. Under perfect competition, all producers (and all consumers) are price takers, and economic profits do not exist.
answerFeedback.9530eab6-42a8-4ca7-86ce-8711231e8fed: Correct. Advertising and product differentiation are most likely to have a positive impact on the economic profits of producers under monopolistic competition. The monopoly aspect of this structure arises from the ability to differentiate its product.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531053
entry.itemBody: A firm in a market environment characterized by monopolistic competition is most likely to:

choices.itemBody: A. continue to experience economic profit in the long run.
B. have a well-defined supply function reflecting its marginal and average costs.
C. have many competitors each following its own product differentiation strategy.

answerFeedback.758aee06-e454-4b9f-9415-7b1bb9876274: Incorrect. Just as with the perfectly competitive market structure, with relatively low entry costs, more firms will enter the market and lure some customers away from the firm making an economic profit. The loss of customers to new entrant firms will drive down the demand for all firms producing similar products. In the long run for the monopolistically competitive firm, economic profit will fall to zero.
answerFeedback.e605a9c0-cb39-485b-814d-8b372a7f340c: Incorrect. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost.
answerFeedback.f59aac36-8b76-4218-9fd5-5853742996cb: Correct. As the name implies, monopolistic competition is a hybrid market structure. The most distinctive factor in monopolistic competition is product differentiation. Although the market is made up of many firms that compose the product group, each producer attempts to distinguish its product from that of the others, and product differentiation is accomplished in a variety of ways.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531054
entry.itemBody:
With its existing production facilities, a monopolist firm can produce up to 100 units. It faces the following demand and cost schedules:

Output (Units) Price ($/Unit) Total Costs ($)
0 3,000 600
20 2,800 10,600
40 2,600 32,600
60 2,400 66,600
80 2,200 112,600
100 2,000 170,600


The optimal output level for this producer (in units) is closest to:

answerFeedback.75936295-221d-4f0a-9050-52697cc12871: Incorrect. Although it is the highest price level (with output > 0), marginal revenue exceeds marginal cost, the profit of $45,400 can be further increased by additional output. Notice though that this is the widest spread between MR and MC.
answerFeedback.8c54ffff-ad70-4417-ab54-9340553a8c0b:
Correct. The optimal output level is 60 units because that level produces the highest profit:

Output (Units) Price ($/Unit) Total Revenue ($) Total Costs ($) Profit ($)
20 2,800 56,000 10,600 45,400
40 2,600 104,000 32,600 71,400
60 2,400 144,000 66,600 77,400
80 2,200 176,000 112,600 63,400
100 2,000 200,000 170,600 29,400
answerFeedback.d9675054-b7f7-417a-b365-3014c8f3608d: Incorrect. Although this is the production capacity level, and the highest level of revenue possible, it should not be the chosen output level because total profit can be increased by lowering production to only 60 units.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531057
entry.itemBody:
Six companies in an industry have the following market shares:

Company A B C D E F
Market Share (%) 30 25 16 12 10 7


If Companies D and F merge into a new Company, G, the industry’s three-company concentration ratio would be closest to:

answerFeedback.14861f43-b802-4bde-bc11-45e9ac46afb3: Incorrect. 72% is the concentration ratio of the top three companies if the two smallest merge: A (30%) + B (25%) + [E (10%) + F (7%)].
answerFeedback.6ef726ac-30e5-4f0a-8d09-2a22068f243a: Incorrect. 71% is the concentration ratio of the original top three companies: A (30%) + B (25%) + C (16%).
answerFeedback.aa75d996-b697-45c0-a9ec-9d0ac82128db:
Correct. The concentration ratio for the top three companies would be 74%:

A (30%) + B (25%) + G (12% + 7%).

entry.title: ITEM_20190530018
entry.itemBody: A manufacturing company expanded in a new region by setting up local assembly lines and hiring local staff. Two years later, the company's sale had grown as expected but operating margin had shrunk from 15 to 12 percent. The company:

choices.itemBody: A. has yet to reach its breakeven volume.
B. is suffering from diseconomies of scale.
C. has reached its minimum efficient scale.

answerFeedback.8ce26cd0-2a3b-4962-9d62-8bbcac4755f0: Incorrect because breakeven is the point where total revenues equal total costs and hence operating profit is zero. The company’s operating margins are positive; therefore, it is operating above breakeven.
answerFeedback.d16c1fa3-667a-45f8-880c-c56d1db26d4f: Incorrect because the minimum point on the LRAC curve is referred to as the minimum efficient scale. Since profits are lower than before the expansion, the company is not yet operating at the least-cost point.
answerFeedback.fcbc0c80-ae50-4f0a-9fba-472ee14185e9: Correct because the company is most likely suffering from diseconomies of scale. It is having to duplicate all costs in each location, and by targeting different demographics, it has added additional costs for inputs and marketing. Therefore, the company’s fixed costs have increased faster than output, and the economic result is diseconomies of scale.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531036
entry.itemBody:
The two dominant supermarket chains in the area are attempting to increase their market share by moving to 24-hour service instead of closing at 9 p.m. every night. The strategic outcomes and payoff matrix that arise from their actions are depicted in the diagram (with the shaded sections representing payoffs for Chain 2).

Expand / Collapse Extended Description

Each square is split in half horizontally. The top half of the square Close at 9 P M, Close at 9 PM is labeled 290; the bottom half is labeled 180. The top half of the square Close at 9 P M, Open 24 hours is labeled 592; the bottom half is labeled 55. The top half of the square Open 24 hours, Close at 9 PM is labeled 75; the bottom half is labeled 540. The top half of the square Open 24 hours, Open 24 hours is labeled 140; the bottom half is labeled 108.

 

The most likely Nash equilibrium strategy for the two chains is for:

choices.itemBody: A. both chains to open for 24 hours.
B. only Chain 2 to open for 24 hours.
C. both chains to close at 9 p.m.

answerFeedback.59ca05b3-63e1-4d7d-935f-cbc4fb67a689:
Correct. Each company will consider the other’s reaction in selecting its strategy. Using the following summary, it is best for both chains to provide 24-hour service.

Chain Consideration Best Decision
  If it opens for 24 hours, it will see a higher payoff regardless of what Chain 2 does.  
  Chain 2 Chain 2  
1 Closes at 9 p.m. Opens for 24 hours Open for 24 hours
  Chain 1 earns 540 instead of 180 Chain 1 earns 108 instead of 55  
  If it opens for 24 hours, it will see a higher payoff regardless of what Chain 1 does.  
  Chain 1 Chain 1  
2 Chain 1
Closes at 9 p.m. 		Chain 1
Opens for 24 hours 		Open for 24 hours
  Chain 2 earns 592 instead of 290 Chain 2 earns 140 instead of 75
answerFeedback.babc7686-f7fc-49a8-a5fc-4e7ecadbfaa7: Incorrect because it produces the highest combined profit from all combinations but is not relevant for any 1 chain in this market environment.
answerFeedback.f26193ea-fcdb-4d7b-9787-0d944e461b75: Incorrect. As indicated in the table, both chains have an incentive to open for 24 hours because they will do better regardless of what their competitor does.

entry.title: ITEM_20170531048
entry.itemBody: Assume that two firms in a duopoly enter into a collusive agreement in an attempt to form a cartel and restrict output, raise prices, and increase profits. According to the Nash equilibrium, a low price is most likely charged by:

answerFeedback.0f8173c6-bb15-417d-94a9-86948f621b74:
Incorrect. The market outcomes for two firms in a duopoly is shown in the diagram. The lower left hand quadrant is the Nash solution when there is no collusion. However, with collusion, if ArcCo shares at least enough of its profit in the bottom right quadrant to provide BatCo more than it would receive in the lower left, it will be the optimal solution for the pair: the maximum joint profits will arise where both firms charge high prices for the product.

Expand / Collapse Extended Description

Top left square is labeled ArcCo Low Price 50 on the top half and BatCo Low Price 70 on the bottom half. Top right square is labeled ArcCo Low Price 80 on the top half and BatCo High Price 0 on the bottom half. Bottom left square is labeled ArcCo High Price 300 on the top half and BatCo Low Price 350 on the bottom half. Bottom right square is labeled ArcCo High Price 500 on the top half and BatCo High Price 300 on the bottom half.
answerFeedback.bbef013c-4789-4358-8038-12b36a1aa8eb: Correct. The market outcomes for two firms in a duopoly is shown in the diagram. The lower left hand quadrant is the Nash solution when there is no collusion. However, with collusion, if ArcCo shares at least enough of its profit in the bottom right quadrant to provide BatCo more than it would receive in the lower left, it will be the optimal solution for the pair: the maximum joint profits will arise where both firms charge high prices for the product.
answerFeedback.d794819b-5447-4ce5-aa94-3db89869f401: Incorrect. The market outcomes for two firms in a duopoly is shown in the diagram. The lower left hand quadrant is the Nash solution when there is no collusion. However, with collusion, if ArcCo shares at least enough of its profit in the bottom right quadrant to provide BatCo more than it would receive in the lower left, it will be the optimal solution for the pair: the maximum joint profits will arise where both firms charge high prices for the product.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Huffman-01
entry.itemBody: In long-run equilibrium, the perfectly competitive firm's supply curve is best represented by the firm's long-run:

answerFeedback.2a3084fe-3a35-4e53-b1d7-de865ca595db: Incorrect because in a perfectly competitive market structure the firm’s demand schedule is the same as the firm’s marginal revenue and average revenue. Given its cost of operation, the only decision the perfectly competitive firm faces is how much to produce. The answer is the level of output that maximizes its return, and that level is where MR = MC. The demand curve is perfectly elastic. Of course, the firm constantly tries to find ways to lower its cost in the long run.
answerFeedback.ad041340-4576-4b2b-a738-3bd8aca938ab: Correct because the long-run marginal cost schedule is the perfectly competitive firm’s supply curve. The firm’s demand curve is dictated by the aggregate market’s equilibrium price. The basic rule of profit maximization is that MR = MC, as is the case in long-run equilibrium.
answerFeedback.f09d40b2-1f02-4e13-9cb2-07dfff6554b1: Incorrect because the horizontal line that represents the firm’s demand curve is the firm’s AR [average revenue] schedule.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Shaw-02
entry.itemBody: Under monopolistic competition, a firm's supply curve is represented by:

choices.itemBody: C. neither average cost nor marginal cost.

answerFeedback.2d07f53b-1dd2-45e3-b381-0243e59953ec: Correct because in perfect competition, the firm’s supply schedule is represented by the marginal cost schedule. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost.
answerFeedback.565d655f-b569-42aa-b329-31ca8a88215a: Incorrect because in perfect competition, the firm’s supply schedule is represented by the marginal cost schedule. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost.
answerFeedback.b482e098-8f62-4c4c-8add-8285cf3a28f0: Incorrect because in perfect competition, the firm’s supply schedule is represented by the marginal cost schedule. In monopolistic competition, there is no well-defined supply function. The information used to determine the appropriate level of output is based on the intersection of MC and MR. However, the price that will be charged is based on the market demand schedule. The firm’s supply curve should measure the quantity the firm is willing to supply at various prices. That information is not represented by either marginal cost or average cost.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Burke-01
entry.itemBody: Under which of the following market structures are pricing strategies most likely influenced by the expected reaction of other firms?

answerFeedback.6afe8e22-b4ae-4752-88f1-d061a8dd4ea9: Correct because the oligopoly market structure is based on a relatively small number of firms supplying the market. The small number of firms in the market means that each firm must consider what retaliatory strategies the other firms will pursue when prices and production levels change. Consider the pricing behavior of commercial airline companies.  Pricing strategies and route scheduling are based on the expected reaction of the other carriers in similar markets.
answerFeedback.75824f17-067c-48a7-b2ce-5a6cf4b53f53: Incorrect because there are many sellers in this type of market structure and firms operating in a market structure or perfect competition are price takers.
answerFeedback.eb0e03a7-7bda-4569-8b6c-c9fc2bf61b5e: Incorrect because there are many sellers and in the case of monopolistic competition, the success of product differentiation determines the degree with which the firm can influence prices.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Islam-04
entry.itemBody: Each oligopoly firm faces an individual demand curve under:

choices.itemBody: C. both colluding and non-colluding market conditions.

answerFeedback.083871da-b96b-4e9f-8a40-5d3cd81139cc: Incorrect because in an oligopoly market where collusion is present, the aggregate market demand curve is divided up by the individual production participants. Under non-colluding market conditions, each firm faces an individual demand curve.
answerFeedback.9a50d728-7f30-4e95-b984-b7e51f7675f9: Correct because in an oligopoly market where collusion is present, the aggregate market demand curve is divided up by the individual production participants. Under non-colluding market conditions, each firm faces an individual demand curve.
answerFeedback.e1a1fe1e-9a6b-4922-95cb-fa2f1e953577: Incorrect because in an oligopoly market where collusion is present, the aggregate market demand curve is divided up by the individual production participants. Under non-colluding market conditions, each firm faces an individual demand curve.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08737
entry.itemBody: In theory, under which of the following market structures do firms have the least control over price?

answerFeedback.aec7e042-c250-47c4-8a8b-ba16fc8720d2: Correct because from the perspective of the owners of the firm, the most desirable market structure is that with the most control over price, because this control can lead to large profits. Monopoly and oligopoly markets offer the greatest potential control over price; monopolistic competition offers less control. Firms operating under perfectly competitive market conditions have no control over price.
answerFeedback.b988b661-b7b3-4127-bb6c-a64807b84746: Incorrect because from the perspective of the owners of the firm, the most desirable market structure is that with the most control over price, because this control can lead to large profits. Monopoly and oligopoly markets offer the greatest potential control over price; monopolistic competition offers less control. Firms operating under perfectly competitive market conditions have no control over price.
answerFeedback.d5456d66-6819-4324-8f5f-3cf71d10309d: Incorrect because from the perspective of the owners of the firm, the most desirable market structure is that with the most control over price, because this control can lead to large profits. Monopoly and oligopoly markets offer the greatest potential control over price; monopolistic competition offers less control. Firms operating under perfectly competitive market conditions have no control over price.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-10679
entry.itemBody: According to the Cournot assumption, in an oligopoly market each firm determines its profit-maximizing production level by assuming that other firms will:

answerFeedback.a2d107f1-dba8-4f83-8a73-92143d6252ac: Correct because in the Cournot assumption, each firm determines its profit-maximizing production level by assuming that the other firms' output will not change. This assumption simplifies pricing strategy because there is no need to guess what the other firm will do to retaliate.
answerFeedback.ad71a4d7-10a0-4904-9397-df0dade22b27: Incorrect because in the Cournot assumption, each firm determines its profit-maximizing production level by assuming that the other firms' output will not change. This assumption simplifies pricing strategy because there is no need to guess what the other firm will do to retaliate.
answerFeedback.b525ea17-b6c9-419f-8769-fcdaea69c60e: Incorrect because in the Cournot assumption, each firm determines its profit-maximizing production level by assuming that the other firms' output will not change. This assumption simplifies pricing strategy because there is no need to guess what the other firm will do to retaliate.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Islam-01
entry.itemBody: Which of the following indicators suggest(s) a monopoly market?

choices.itemBody: C. Both a concentration ratio of 100% and a Herfindahl–Hirschman index of zero

answerFeedback.66385bf0-289a-4637-acb8-d7c241c4fdad: Correct because the concentration ratio is the sum of the market shares of the largest N firms. This number is always between zero (perfect competition) and 100 percent (monopoly).
answerFeedback.b0a45c22-10fd-4f0a-9568-9eda25679f1b: Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1.
answerFeedback.dab7ad78-80c2-4e33-954a-c4c0691a53ef: Incorrect because O.C. Herfindahl and A.O. Hirschman suggested an index where the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Islam-02
entry.itemBody: The Herfindahl–Hirschman index is calculated based on:

choices.itemBody: C. probability of new entry into the market.

answerFeedback.50632297-b721-434a-ab7c-3bb4b14ee8bf: Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand.
answerFeedback.95ca14c5-9773-4a4d-9653-13264a6e0768: Incorrect because just like the concentration ratio, the HHI does not take the possibility of entry into account, nor does it consider the elasticity of demand.
answerFeedback.d4fbab1d-c427-44e2-b33c-34ca0380a908: Correct because in calculating the Herfindahl–Hirschman index the market shares of the top N companies are first squared and then added. If one firm controls the whole market (a monopoly), the Herfindahl–Hirschman index (HHI) equals 1. If there are M firms in the industry with equal market shares, then the HHI equals (1/M).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Chan-02
entry.itemBody: Which of the following market structures has high barriers to entry?

answerFeedback.3f3362e7-06a1-4f09-b676-75fb73327fc7: Incorrect because monopolistic competition has low barriers to entry.
answerFeedback.4049d296-6e4b-42a8-935c-fed12bebc6ce: Correct because the characteristics of oligopoly markets include: entry into the market is difficult, with fairly high costs and significant barriers to competition.
answerFeedback.d310fb43-ca08-457c-968b-b79d6d92c355: Incorrect because perfect competition has very low barriers to entry.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020-C2-Econ-Erickson-02
entry.itemBody: Under which of the following market structures is product differentiation most important?

answerFeedback.0d954821-d0ae-43ce-8986-d14596eb6b44: Incorrect because the least competitive market structure is monopoly. In pure monopoly markets, there are no other good substitutes for the given product or service. There is a single seller, which, if allowed to operate without constraint, exercises considerable power over pricing and output decisions.
answerFeedback.aab096b7-3409-41bf-8c02-c0bffe591271: Correct because monopolistic competition is also highly competitive; however, it is considered a form of imperfect competition. The competitive characteristic is a notably large number of firms, while the monopoly aspect is the result of product differentiation. That is, if the seller can convince consumers that its product is uniquely different from other, similar products, then the seller can exercise some degree of pricing power over the market.
answerFeedback.ccc37681-938b-4ff3-83d6-8eba28d60102: Incorrect because perfect competition is a reality—for example, in several commodities markets, where sellers and buyers have a strictly homogeneous product and no single producer is large enough to influence market prices. Product differentiation is not possible under perfect competition.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-2020B-Econ-Milosevic-08
entry.itemBody:
An analyst gathers the following information (in $ millions) about a firm operating in a perfectly competitive market:

Total variable costs 700
Total fixed costs 400

If the firm's total revenue is $1,000 million, the firm should:

choices.itemBody: A. stay in the market in both the short run and long run.
B. stay in the market in the short run and exit the market in the long run.
C. shut down production in the short run and exit the market in the long run.

answerFeedback.54e75730-1785-442c-ae54-d7b3d3ad325f: Correct because when TR (total revenue) is enough to cover TVC (total variable costs) but not all of TFC (total fixed costs), the firm can continue to produce in the short run but will be unable to maintain financial solvency in the long run. TR is $1,000 which is greater than TVC of $700, but not enough to cover the firm's TFC of $400. Therefore the firm will exit the market in the long run.
answerFeedback.a9ef4e86-da9b-452f-b867-1b0f55c89e65: Incorrect because TR > TVC but < TC. Therefore, the firm will stay in the market in the short run because TR is enough to cover TVC but not all of TFC, the firm can continue to produce in the short run.
answerFeedback.b38354d1-747a-48e1-b2a6-bd4d8387359f: Incorrect because TR > TVC but < TC. As such the firm will stay in the market in the short run and exit the market in the long run.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-08710
entry.itemBody: A perfectly competitive market structure:

choices.itemBody: B. causes all industries to ultimately fail due to lack of profits.
C. drives company profits to the investors' required rate of return.

answerFeedback.0bf17745-83a2-4c37-bfe6-89bb1c3c1ae5: Incorrect because perfect competition does not mean that all perfectly competitive industries are doomed to extinction by a lack of profits. On the contrary, millions of businesses that do very well are living under the pressures of perfect competition.
answerFeedback.8cd80d4c-b1dc-4e5a-b177-7ef147af10b7: Incorrect because unlike some economic concepts, perfect competition is not merely an ideal based on assumptions. Perfect competition is a reality.
answerFeedback.9a66ecbf-70b3-491c-87e9-5ade7dbbba12: Correct because profits under the conditions of perfect competition are driven to the required rate of return paid by the entrepreneur to borrow capital from investors (so-called normal profit or rental cost of capital).

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-L1-09910
entry.itemBody: In the short run, a firm most likely shuts down production when:

choices.itemBody: B. sunk costs are greater than total revenue.
C. total revenue is less than total variable cost.

answerFeedback.65b5c04b-54c3-4084-8699-5a8bb8574a0a: Incorrect because sunk costs cannot be avoided, no matter what the firm does. Sunk costs must be ignored in the decision to continue to operate in the short run. As long as the firm's revenues cover at least its variable cost, the firm is better off continuing to operate.
answerFeedback.aa6cb1cb-328b-49ab-9742-dd27ef01521a: Incorrect because in the long run, if a firm cannot earn at least a zero economic profit, it will not operate because it is not covering the opportunity cost of all of its factors of production, labor, and capital. In the short run, however, a firm might find it advantageous to continue to operate even if it is not earning at least a zero economic profit. Firms will stay in business (short and long run) if they make a zero profit.
answerFeedback.ba870d8a-cbab-4e45-b39f-b8dda2a56b4b: Correct because the firm must cover its variable cost to remain in business in the short run. If TR cannot cover TVC, the firm shuts down production to minimize loss. The loss would be equal to the amount of fixed cost.

entry.title: ITEM_CFA-MC-2022.03-Econ-Huffman-06
entry.itemBody: A disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it:

choices.itemBody: A. requires a large number of time-series observations.
B. is largely unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents.
C. requires the specification of the explanatory variables used in regression analysis.

answerFeedback.80380542-3b51-4614-ac15-d24763fcf866: Incorrect because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Alternative measures such as regression analysis is useful in computing elasticity but requires a large number of observations. Therefore, one may use a time-series approach and, for example, look at 20 years of quarterly sales data for a market. However, the market structure may have changed radically over those 20 years.
answerFeedback.82d12494-cf1c-472a-a164-6eeaf5a50fcb: Correct because a disadvantage of the concentration ratio is that it tends to be unaffected by mergers among the top market incumbents. For example, if the largest and second-largest incumbents merge, the pricing power of the combined entity is likely to be larger than that of the two pre-existing companies. But the concentration ratio may not change much.
answerFeedback.d6d4d844-7447-4bac-ac3b-b61e2e819076: Incorrect because because the main advantage of the concentration ratio is that it is simple to compute. Further, an alternative approach is a cross-sectional regression analysis. Different specifications of the explanatory variables (for example, using total GDP rather than median household income or per-capita GDP to represent income) may sometimes lead to dramatically different estimates.
